final_poem:
## The Long Hours

Time is the kind of leak
that widens under water,
not splintering wood but stretching
the fabric of what happened
into a thing with no edges,
no place to stand on.

I watched my grandmother fold
a newspaper the way some people
fold money — not for storage
but because the crease
was cheaper than the paper it took,
each press reducing her palm
to something almost architectural,
almost without thickness.

That was forty years ago.
The folds are still there, exact,
the way a dog remembers
the sound of a door it left behind
in another country. Time
doesn't erase. It just
rearranges what's left
into a smaller room.

I tell my children about the 7:14 train
that used to pull through town before darkness —
how I remember watching for it
from the window of a building
where nothing changed, where the woman on the third floor
left milk out on the sill every morning
and never once worried about the trains.

They listen. They believe me up to a point.
After thirteen years old, children
begin to calibrate your truth
against what they can verify,
and that calibration is itself
a kind of time — gradual, domestic,
the way a body learns to settle
into a chair that isn't quite right.

But here's the thing: I still hear
the 7:14. It runs through the building.
It rumbles under the sill where there is now
only milk gone stale and no one
left watching.

Time, if you could hold it,
would feel like the woman's worry —
small, specific, impossible to prove
to anyone but yourself,
and even then, just mostly.

I keep meaning to write down
exactly what I wanted to say about this.
But the words float away
the way a clock loses its weight
when you open it, and then
you hear the hour from inside
the mechanism, precise
as something that never changed.
